item.title: Malawi Aims for Third-Time Lucky With IMF Deal After Election
item.description: Malawi has had a tough time keeping track of its International Monetary Fund programs that bring in much-needed financing, failing twice in the last five years to conclude them. The government plans a fresh effort after the September elections.
item.dc:creator: Frank Jomo

item.title: Dollar Weakness Fuels Unusual Surge in Currency Volatility
item.description: The dollar’s descent is elevating the price of hedging currency trades around the world, breaking up a long-standing market conviction that costs tend to come down when the greenback weakens.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Bridgestone Eyes Price Hikes, More US Output to Counter Tariffs
item.description: Bridgestone Corp. is expanding production in the Americas and considering raising prices to offset the impact from tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Reina Sasaki

item.title: German Bonds May Be More Attractive Than US, JPM Says
item.description: JPMorgan global markets strategy head Dubravko Lakos-Bujas discusses the outlook for European fixed income markets. "I do think that the German bond market, in terms of supply, actually looks quite attractive and maybe in some cases more attractive than sort of the US side," Lakos-Bujas says. He speaks to Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua on the sidelines of the JPMorgan Capital Markets Conference in Paris. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Bonds Seen at Risk of Liz Truss Moment as Deficit Balloons
item.description: Eurizon SLJ’s Jen says market blowup may be needed to force fiscal restraint
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick, Phil Serafino

item.title: Merck KGaA Cuts Outlook on Tariff Risks, Currency Turmoil
item.description: Merck KGaA, the German science and technology group, trimmed its profit forecast, citing a weakening US dollar and uncertainty around global tariffs. The stock tumbled.
item.dc:creator: Sonja Wind

item.title: Ruble Hits Two-Year High as Istanbul Talks Expected With Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s currency rose to its strongest level against the dollar in two years as negotiators arrived in Turkey for what are expected to be the first direct talks between Moscow and Kyiv since 2022 and domestic appetite for foreign-currency dropped.
item.dc:creator: Kira Zavyalova

item.title: LG Chem Seeks $1 Billion for Bonds Exchangeable Into LG Energy Solution Shares
item.description: South Korea’s LG Chem Ltd. is seeking to raise $1 billion in bonds that can be exchanged for shares in LG Energy Solution Ltd. to refinance another issuance.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian

media:content.media:description: The LG Chem Ltd. plant in the Yeosu Industrial Complex in South Korea.

item.title: Options Pros Jettison S&P 500 Hedges as Rally Forces About-Face
item.description: For equity-options traders, greed now has firmly replaced fear as they dive into bullish positions on expectations that US stocks will extend their rebound from the depths seen last month.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

item.title: Stocks Slide as Risk Appetite Fades; Oil Tumbles: Markets Wrap
item.description: Global stocks fell alongside oil prices as investors pulled away from risky assets with the enthusiasm over Wall Street’s rally continuing to dim.
item.dc:creator: Margaryta Kirakosian

media:content.media:description: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers praised US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent for getting China to agree to a 90-day pause on tariffs. He calls it a good thing for the US economy. He spoke on Bloomberg Television’s Wall Street Week with David Westin.

item.title: Nippon Life to Stop Sending Staff to Sales Departments at Banks
item.description: Nippon Life Insurance Co. will discontinue the practice of temporarily sending employees to work in sales departments of other firms such as banks, judging that the arrangements may distort fair competition.
item.dc:creator: Nao Sano

item.title: Banxico Is Expected to Deliver Half-Point Rate Cut
item.description: Mexico will likely maintain the pace of monetary policy easing Thursday, offering up a half-point rate cut as the economy shows signs of prolonged weakness with inflation inside the target range.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

item.title: New World Hasn’t Given Perpetual Bond Call Notice, Holders Say
item.description: Some holders of a New World Development Co. perpetual bond said they haven’t received redemption notices on the note, as a deadline loomed that would trigger higher interest costs on the facility.
item.dc:creator: Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu, Apple Ka Ying Li

item.title: CaixaBank, Sabadell Finalize Risk Transfers as Bank M&A Heats Up
item.description: CaixaBank SA and Banco Sabadell SA are finalizing significant risk transfers to free up capital for growth amid consolidation in the Spanish financial industry.

item.title: Oil Extends Drop as Trump Says US Is Closer to Deal With Iran
item.description: Oil fell for a second day after President Donald Trump said the US and Iran are getting closer to a deal on the country’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Oil storage containers in Midland, Texas, US, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. Oil steadied following its biggest one-day jump in almost a year as fears that Israel may decide to strike Iranian crude facilities in retaliation for a missile barrage kept the market on edge.

item.title: Trump’s Tax-Cut Plan Will Cost Trillions More, Watchdog Finds
item.description: The cost of Republican lawmakers’ draft plan for sweeping tax cuts weighed in at $3.8 trillion over the next 10 years in one official estimate. The reality is likely much higher, thanks to the use of budget and political tools designed to minimize the appearance of the fiscal hit, according to independent analysts including former Republican staff members.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Nancy Cook

item.title: ‘Clear Signs’ Oil Demand Growth Is Slowing: IEA’s Bosoni
item.description: Toril Bosoni, International Energy Agency oil markets head, discusses the outlook for global oil demand as the IEA said it is expected to slow down for the rest of 2025 amid economic headwinds. “We’re seeing an oversupplied market for the remainder of this year and extending into 2026,” Bosoni tells Bloomberg’s Francine Lacqua.

item.title: Siemens Sees Decline in Orders for Data Center Products
item.description: Siemens AG’s sales of electrical products for data centers fell, signaling a possible slowdown in an industry that has fueled the German manufacturer’s growth in recent quarters.
item.dc:creator: Wilfried Eckl-Dorna, Oliver Crook

media:content.media:description: A logo sits illuminated outside the Siemens AG gas turbine factory in Berlin, Germany, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Siemens is considering the future of a controversial contract to supply signaling systems to a new Australian coal mine under pressure from environmental activists, who staged German-wide protests against the company on Friday. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Romanian Election Brings Junk-Level Risks for Bond Investors
item.description: Investors are treating Romania’s eurobonds on par with junk-rated debt after months of political turmoil, and now the weekend’s presidential ballot brings fresh risks for the currency and local debt as well.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Campaign posters for presidential candidates in Bucharest. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Bloomberg

item.title: Top Hong Kong Builder Sells Out Homes in Hours as Rates Fall
item.description: Hong Kong’s biggest property developer Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. sold out the first batch of homes for a new project within hours, as the lowest mortgage rates in more than two years lured buyers.

item.title: Euronext CEO Says Investors Reducing Exposure to US
item.description: Euronext CEO Stephane Boujnah says volatility in US decision making is pushing investors to reduce their exposure and relocate some assets into Europe. He spoke to Bloomberg's Tom Mackenzie from Amsterdam on "Daybreak: Europe." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.description: European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson warned against excessively reducing the ESG reporting and regulatory burden on European companies.

item.title: Odd Lots: The Double Whammy Facing Oil Companies (Podcast)
item.description: The new administration has a “drill, baby, drill” mantra and a much more liberal attitude towards the oil and gas industry than the last one. But that hasn’t translated into great profits for the oil industry itself. Crude prices have sunk and tariffs have raised the cost of components for companies trying to get energy out of the ground. So, what’s the future for the industry? And who is actually making money right now? In this episode, we talk to longtime energy industry veteran Peter Tertzaki
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: Russia Oil-Export Revenue at Lowest Since 2023 as Prices Slump
item.description: Russia’s oil-export revenues in April fell to the lowest in nearly two years as global crude prices declined amid sluggish demand, according to the International Energy Agency.

item.title: Oil ‘More Negative, Quicker’ If Iran Back, Blanch Says
item.description: Francisco Blanch, head of global commodities, equity derivatives and cross-asset quantitative investment strategies at Bank of America Global Research, discusses the oil market as crude fell for a second day after President Donald Trump said the US and Iran are getting closer to a deal on the country’s nuclear program. He speaks on Bloomberg Television.
